35777105.review:
[h1]Story[/h1]
Die gesamte Vogelschaft ist hypnotisiert und folgt dem finsteren Schurken "Baron Breitbart". Dieser will mit den Vögeln den lang vergessenen Schatz seines Bruders finden. Dies zu verhindern und die Vögel zu befreien liegt nun in unserer, bzw. in Nelly Cootalots Hand.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Ein klassisches Point&Click mit kleinen Minispielen zwischendurch. Dabei sammelt man, ganz klassisch, einen Haufen Schmarrn im Inventar. Auch hat man einen kleinen Vogel als Sidekick, der bei einigen Rätseln hilft. 

[h1]Grafik und Sound[/h1]
Alle Schauplätze sind detailreich und liebevoll gezeichnet und auch die Charaktere wissen zu gefallen. Auch die Tonausgabe ist (im Deutschen) stimmig und überzeugt durch Wortwitz und unterschiedlichste Sprecher. Immer wieder ertönt außerdem ein Liedchen, dass an die Deponia-Reihe erinnert und das Spielgeschehen amüsant begleitet.

[h1]Steuerung[/h1]
Die Maus ist wie bei vielen Point&Clicks das Eingabegerät erster Wahl, aber auch der Controllersupport funktioniert. Mit Hilfe der Leertaste lassen sich außerdem Hotspots anzeigen.

[h1]Schwierigkeit[/h1]
Die Puzzles im Spiel waren mir leider etwas zu einfach. Viel zu schnell kommt man auf die richtige Lösung und es gibt keine alternativen Lösungen. Auch die Minispiele sind recht einfach gehalten. Dies hat zum einen den Vorteil, dass Nelly Cootalot auch für die jüngeren Spieler ein Erlebnis ist, jedoch das Spiel auch sehr verkürzt.

[h1]Spielzeit[/h1]
Womit wir beim nächsten Punkt sind. Trotz Achivementjagt war bei mir das Ende nach 4 Stunden erreicht. Das empfinde ich für ein Adventure in dieser Preisklasse leider als etwas zu wenig. Durch die nichtvorhandenen unterschiedlichen Lösungsmöglichkeiten hat man dann auch alles im Spiel gesehen und wirklich etwas zu entdecken gibt es dann nichts mehr. Auch fesselt oder bewegt die Story nicht so sehr, dass sich ein erhöhter Wiederspielwert ergibt.


[h1]Fazit[/h1]
Es ist schwierig hier für Nelly Cootalot eine abschließende Bewertung abzugeben. Das Spiel macht vieles richtig aber leider auch einiges nicht. Das Grundgerüst ist toll. Die Charaktäre, die Sprachausgabe, die Details an den jeweiligen Orten und auch der manchmal leicht abgedrehte Humor. Leider macht es das Spiel dem Spieler leider zu einfach so, dass Genrefans hier schnell alle Rätsel gelöst haben. Die dadurch kurze Spielzeit wirkt dann, in Anbetracht des Preises, enttäuschend. Hier hätte sich das Spiel mehr Zeit nehmen sollen um die Charaktere etwas genauer zu beleuchten. Auch wären knackigere Rätsel und Minigames wünschenswert gewesen. So musste nur selten etwas im Inventar kombiniert werden. Zudem wird immer wieder auf die Vorgeschichte verwiesen, die es wohl kostenlos im Internet zu spielen gibt. Hier stellt sich die Frage, warum dies nicht ins Spiel inkludiert wird/wurde.


Alles in allem bleibt Nelly Cootalot für mich ein gutes, aber nicht sehr gutes Point&Click, dass durch seinen Preis den Konkurrenzkampf mit anderen Spielen verliert. Ich kann das Spiel zum Vollpreis leider nicht empfehlen.

34814851.review:
This point and click adventure game by Alasdair Beckett-King and Application Systems Heidelberg feature a female pirate captain Nelly Cootalot. While working aboard a ship HMS Undeliverable that was delivering mail to Port Rubicund, Nelly receives a visit by her spiritual mentor Captain William Bloodbeard, telling her to pursue William's brother Baron Widebeard to stop him from a plot to hypnotize, control and raise an army of birds to go after an object of great power.

The game has more than 90 positive reviews at the time of this review, has a funny and entertaining cast of characters with funny and witty dialogue, great voiced dialogue and songs with vocals, cute and comical hand-drawn graphics and animation for every character and talking bird in the game, a fast travel option in one large port town and the option to show all objects and characters that Nelly can look and interact with and puzzles, minigames and achievements that are easy to solve, complete and obtain. Overall, highly recommended when at discount for those who like a great comedic point and click adventure game that is casual and forgiving for all types of players and don't mind a few minor bugs in the game. (I spotted 2 bugs during my playthrough, there is a bug that occurs rarely where sometimes selecting an item to try to combine with another item on inventory as an invalid item pair combination will somehow fail to close the inventory window and it is not possible to use the item on anything in the external environment until a delay afterwards. The second bug is the achievement Timewaster where it is not automatically awarded upon obtaining the second last achievement and the player has to close and restart the game to obtain the final achievement. Thank you ASHGAMES, Saraphel and Alexander Henn for working to fix this bug as mentioned in the game's discussion forums. Developers also appear to be quite responsive to bug reports on the game and have provided a contact e-mail in the game's discussion forums to address all reported bugs.)

30860107.review:
Una simpatica avventura piratesca, ma di poche pretese. Inizialmente, a causa della rappresentazione dolciotta di Nelly e di una impostazione da sequel nei suoi monologhi, avevo il sospetto che fosse tutta una sua fantasticheria, ma così non è, la storia della rossa piratessa con la gonna è vera e andrà portata a termine fino in fondo. 

L'impostazione da sequel però non è casuale né è stata una mia erronea interpretazione, infatti The Fowl Fleet non è la prima scorribanda della nostra eroina, dato che in passato il suo autore, con uno stile più disegnato e gradevole, realizzò un titoletto gratuito intitolato Spoonbeaks Ahoy. 

Questo secondo capitolo, con animazioni limitate, difficoltà a fermare un'azione intrapresa e dialoghi talvolta lenti ad alternarsi, specie se impostate il click per leggerli con calma, si è rivelato nel complesso decisamente gradevole, ma piuttosto pacatella come avventura grafica. Per essere esatti, tutto il mondo intorno a Nelly lo è, in linea con disegni magari simpatici, ma non certo  belli da vedere. L'impostazione è quella di un prodotto kinder che tenta di essere  blandamente impertinente, e la cosa non è negativa, negativo semmai è che una manciata di discorsi cadano su allusioni adulte parecchio fuori dallo spirito giovane di questo punta e clicca.

Tra i pregi, oltre a delle canzoncine orecchiabili, gli va annoverata un'ottima traduzione italiana, che adatta anche alcuni nomi dei personaggi, aumentando o meglio restituendo il corretto senso di merendine all'olio di palma di cui il gioco si ammanta. "Rocco Scirocco" direi che rende bene l'idea. Purtroppo però Nelly ha un grosso limite,  la longevità, accorciata anche da un livello di difficoltà facilotto. 

Nelly Cootalot The Fowl Fleet è un grazioso prodotto, ma adatto soprattutto ai neofiti, gli altri termineranno il gioco entro 5 ore, decisamente sotto lo standard minimo del genere, di conseguenza mi sento di consigliarlo solo se lo trovate ad un prezzo stracciato. 


Ps: L'accostamento a Monkey island per via dell'ambientazione è ridicolo, comunque, vi sono un paio di citazioni al classico della Lucasarts.

29577699.review:
Nelly Cootalot is a point-and-click adventure game where you star as an amateur/ferocious (??) pirate named Nelly. 

In short, this game is very much like a long lost "Monkey Island" sequel that was never released. Nelly could well be Guybrush's and Elaine's daughter, if they ever got one. She's got Elaine's red hair and attitude, and Guybrush's witty and quirky sense of humour. Like the latter, she wants to be a pirate, but is absolutely clueless about how life at sea works.

The humour is the best part of the game. It's witty and, once again, resembles Monkey Island in almost every aspect, though with a few twists. The graphics are gorgeous. Everything is hand-drawn and incredibly detailed. You can stare at the backgrounds for minutes, over and over, and still notice new things each time you come back. The characters are fun and memorable (highlights include a Dylan-wannabe busker and a great, spooky villain by the name of Van Zandt). The soundtrack is above average and fits very well with the game.

The puzzles are well-balanced. It's fun to figure out what you're supposed to be doing and they're never too difficult. It may take some time to realize what you're supposed to do sometimes, but most of the time, you just have to think a little bit and explore the wonderful backgrounds in the game and look for details you can use. In other words, it's even a joy to get stuck and come back later. You want to come back to the game.

Nelly's charmingly British accent is also welcome in an over-exaggerated market of mostly American games. It also adds to the witty nature of the game.

The only criticism I have is that the game is relatively short. I finished it in a total of seven hours in my first run. It would also be nice to have a higher difficulty setting to choose, so you could come back later and explore even more things. There are also some problems with the control, where you sometimes have to wait for Nelly walk to the next room once you've clicked, even if you click on something else before she gets there. But these complaints are very minor.

Overall, I absolutely loved this game. It takes me back to a time (circa 1997) when point-and-click adventures were still around and flourishing. It's the best find I've done in quite a while and the perfect compliment for you if you're waiting the Monkey Island sequel that never arrives.

29575875.review: Really is a terrific, well made game. Good writing, good level design, good music, good voice acting. Funny, and with loads of little touches that remind you over and over just how much the developers cared about the product. If you liked the old LucasArts adventure games, this is the closest thing I've found to them - a little less serious, a little less difficult, a little less expansive, but a game that will put a smile on your face and not let it drop until the second you finish. And even then, they made the credits a joy too.

28998525.review:
Best part of this game is the ending song, but that's because it’s really great ending to a solidly great game.  No mind blowing puzzle difficulty, but several chuckle worthy moments and classic point and click game play. Oh and Tom Baker provides voice acting, that’s pretty awesome.

Nelly Cootalot: The Fowl Fleet is the sequel to a free game that was released quite some time ago. I didn't realize that while playing the game until I Googled. There are several moments in the game that allude to the previous game in some way, such as the opening.  That said you really don’t need to play the previous game to enjoy this one, only know that a world and characters already exist.

The game channels much of Secret of Monkey Island unabashedly. It’s even brought up in game.  That’s okay. Nelly Cootalot takes similar world and works with its own themes. There’s not a lot swashbuckling, mostly fetching drinks and food for people, also insurance fraud. The game goes for the same zany if it puns it works logic that Monkey Island did, but it doesn’t go nearly as far as they did. (Anyone remember the Monkey Wrench?)
Puzzle are pretty simple, a no point did I feel the need to search for hints. Many puzzles are pun related, some are just fetch quests, nothing that requires deep thought.  If anything, the simplicity of the puzzles is the weakest point of the game, but not so bad as to not recommend it.

The voice acting is solid, with Tom Baker standing out far ahead of the rest. While he is does have a major roll, it’s in the form of a hint/helper.  Aside from a handful of puzzles, you really don’t need to speak to his character often. Hints just aren’t that necessary. I found myself interacting with the character just cause.

There was 1 minor bug, hotspots would stop working randomly. Not a huge issue, but could make completing achievements trickier.

Overall, a great game, simple but with a lot of love and care put into it.

28222375.review:
I absolutely loved this. A sweet, gentle and genuinely very funny point and click adventure game. Good, solid, silly sense of humour throughout. I thought the characters, animation and voice acting were brilliant, and the puzzles fairly logical (in a silly way) and solveable without getting stuck for ages and having to use walkthroughs.

On the downside, perhaps it's a little short (it was certainly a shame when it ended, though the ending was really good), but I felt I definitely got my money's worth for the fun and enjoyment. Had me genuinely laughing out loud every 5 minutes or so, and left me feeling warm and happy.

Basically it has everything I loved about playing the first Monkey Island on the Amiga all those years ago, but with a range of British accents and cultural references, sillier British humour and an adorable main character.

Found no bugs at all, and worked perfectly on Ubuntu 16.04.

I hope they do another one, or a cartoon or something with the same world and characters. I'd be really Interested in seeing some of Alasdair Becket-King (or Becket, King)'s other comedy work.

Absolutely lovely.

26185472.review:
Nelly Cootalot: The Fowl Fleet is a delightful adventure game with fantastic humor, a surprisingly large cast of characters (with great voice acting), and puzzles which are, indeed, quite fair.  What difficulty there is generally just comes from the game's "main" middle area which is the largest, and simply has an awful lot to explore and look through before you can get a good handle on what your goals are.  If you ever do feel at a loss for what to do, the game thoughtfully allows you to ask your sidekick Sebastian, who will provide some pointers.  It's a great touch.  The game follows the Lucasarts philosophy of adventure games, so it's impossible to get into a no-win situation.

The main draw really is the humor, and the excellent delivery with which the lines are generally given.  Tom Baker, as Sebastian, is of course great, but Nelly Cootalot herself is voiced flawlessly, and it was a treat to have her as the protagonist.  There were many times I laughed out loud (for real!), and many lines I couldn't resist sharing with friends.

Anyway: highly recommended if you enjoy this kind of adventure game.  I'm looking forward to any more Nelly Cootalot adventures which may find their way to release!

Forse è giusto specificare prima che ho preso parte a questo progetto, ma che non ho NESSUN interesse economico personale che il gioco venda bene su Steam.

Il mio tempo di gioco qui è basso, ma ho finito Nelly Cootalot: The Fowl Fleet più di una volta e lo conosco molto bene.
I suoi punti di forza sono la grafica 2D meravigliosa disegnata a mano e il geniale umorismo inglese dei dialoghi. Il gioco è veramente spassoso.

Ho letto che alcuni si lamentano della durata di gioco. Forse ignorando la metà dei dialoghi e finito il gioco in più in fretta possibile si raggiungono poche ore di gioco, ma prendendosi il tempo di ammirare gli scenari e interagire con i personaggi la storia è lunga e intricata.

Nelly attraverso almeno cinque mondi diversi che spesso contengono altre stanze al loro interno. Gli oggetti e i personaggi con cui si può interagire sono molti, quindi la varietà non manca.
Sulla difficoltà dei rompicapo dipende probabilmente dall'esperienza dei giocatori. A me non sono sembrati per niente banali.

Il prezzo è sicuramente alto, ma bisogna tenere conto che questo gioco è il frutto di centinaia di ore di lavoro di più persone e la passione che ci è stata messo dentro si vede tutta.

22971458.review:
[i]"Быть может, в редких случаях, когда борьба за правое дело заставляет стать пиратом, пиратство может стать правым делом".[/i]

Главная героиня [b]Nelly Cootalot: The Fowl Fleet[/b] - самый настоящий [b]Гайбраш Трипвуд[/b] в юбке! Пусть до звания одного из лучших персонажей компьютерных игр Нелли еще далеко, она очень старается. 

По сюжету игры мы отправляемся на поиски сокровищ Семи Морей, за которыми также охотится давний противник героини [i]Baron Widebeard[/i]. Как и принято по законам жанра, помимо основного задания нам предстоит выполнить еще множество менее важных, чтобы добраться до искомой цели. Кроме этого, коварный пират загипнотизировал целую армаду пернатых, которые должны помочь ему справиться с легендарной охраной аж 70-го и выше уровня! 

Приготовьтесь к большому количеству диалогов, пропитанных изрядной толикой английского юмора. Каждый персонаж в [b]Nelly Cootalot: The Fowl Fleet[/b] играет свою, пусть и небольшую, но важную роль. Взять хотя бы того же французского аристократа, сбежавшего от революционеров из-за их агрессивности, но не испытывающего страха к местному окружению. Помогать в путешествии будет птица по имени Себастьян, единственный уцелевший пернатый, имеющий свое неповторимое мнение о каждом встречном.

Головоломки в игре интересны и логичны. Их наберется чуть более десятка, и особых затруднений они не должны вызвать. Как правило - это задачки на логические рассуждение. Тем кто не любит пиксель-хантинг, который отнимает порой очень много времени на поиски предметов, может вздохнуть спокойно. Нажатием "Пробела" мы можем увидеть все объекты на локации. Поэтому, если вы будете достаточно внимательны, то не пропустите квестовых предметов. Найденные предметы можно комбинировать. Еще одним спасательным кругом является карта, с помощью которой вы сможете перемещаться по архипелагу, на котором будет происходить большая часть событий. 

Если говорить о визуальной части, то все выглядит довольно симпатично, но все же не дотягивает до работ студии [b]Daedalic Entertainment[/b]. 

Самым большим минусом игры является ее непродолжительность. Квестоман со стажем сможет пройти игру за какие-то четыре-пять часов, хотя если вы хотите познакомиться со всеми достопримечательностями, попробовать выйти победителем из ряда мини-игр, то можете прибавить еще часа три.

[u]Плюсы:[/u]
+ Харизматичная главная героиня.
+ Забавный сюжет.
+ Юмор.
+ Мини-игры, призванные немного разнообразить геймплей.
+ Логичные загадки.
+ Интересные диалоги.
+ Отсутствие пиксель-хантинга
+ Удобная карта
+ Себастьян, не уступающий в харизме главной героине.

[u]Минусы:[/u]
- Малая продолжительность.

[u]Итог:[/u]
[i][b]Nelly Cootalot: The Fowl Fleet[/b] - качественный квест для самого широкого круга игроков, с единственной оговоркой. Надо владеть английским языком на довольно высоком уровне, чтобы проникнуться всей атмосферой происходящего. Моя оценка 8 баллов из 10![/i]

22705053.review:
Nelly Cootalot so thoroughly embraces its retro inspirations, that an uncharitable person might call it out-dated. However, it breezes along with such warm-hearted charm, boundless likability, and its none-more-British sense of humour that it's hard to criticise. It's populated with a cast of great characters, with the eponymous Nelly as the pirate heroine out to save all bird-kind from the schemes of her nemesis, Baron Widebeard. The puzzles are fair, logical, and satisfying to solve; you'll rarely spend time trying random inventory items with everything in sight and are unlikely to be forced to consult a walkthrough. Don't forget to consult your fowl companion, Sebastian, for some of the games funniest lines and hints if you lose track of what you're doing.

This game is an easy recommendation for fans of pirate adventures of yesteryear (you know the ones...) and point-and-click games in general. You'll spend your entire playthrough with a big smile on your face or your money back (maybe).

22378199.review:
[i]Humoriste, comédien, réalisateur, Alasdair Beckett-King possède un éventail de talents impressionnant. Et il ne s'arrête pas là. De son imagination foisonnante est né le personnage de Nelly Cootalot, une jeune pirate rousse et espiègle dont les premières aventures qu'il a illustrées et animées étaient disponibles gratuitement. Aujourd'hui l'aventure continue avec "The Fowl Fleet", un projet plus long, plus ambitieux et déjà encensé par la presse vidéoludique.[/i]

Nelly Cootalot est appelée par son mentor, le vénérable pirate William Barbesang à se lancer dans une quête pour contrecarrer les plans machiavéliques du Baron Grandebarbe. Fervente protectrice des oiseaux, Nelly ne réfléchit pas une seconde lorsqu'elle apprend que le Baron les a capturés afin de servir ses projets et se lance à sa poursuite passant ainsi par un ensemble d'îles méridionales où les pirates sont rois et par une contrée viking perdue dans le Grand Nord.

Lors des prémices de l'aventure, j'avais le sentiment étrange et désagréable que le jeu était lisse, sans profondeur. Pourquoi ? La raison principale est que, ayant mis le jeu en français celui-ci était sous-titré (avec des sous-titres d'excellente qualité, je tiens à le préciser) mais les doublages étaient absents, laissant ainsi les personnages remuer la bouche sans qu'aucun son ne s'en échappe. C'est surtout ce point-là qui était étrange : pourquoi inclure une animation des lèvres s'il n'y a pas de doublages ? C'est après coup que j'ai compris, le jeu est doublé en anglais et en allemand mais ne possède que des sous-titres pour ses versions française, italienne et espagnole. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=659370822 Pour gagner en immersion j'ai passé le jeu en anglais et il est bien dommage de ne pouvoir combiner sous-titres français et voix anglaises, donc si vous comprenez et lisez bien l'anglais activez les doublages, sinon vous devrez vous contenter de simples sous-titres. [url=http://steamcommunity.com/app/317320/discussions/0/385428943465731959/]Il est possible cependant que ce souci ne soit que provisoire car suite aux demandes des joueurs, une fonction permettant de combiner voix anglaises/allemandes et sous-titres d'une langue différente est reconsidérée par le créateur[/url]. [Mise à jour du 21/12/16 : Finalement l'attente aura porté ses fruits, les développeurs ont mis en place l'option permettant d'avoir les voix anglaises et les sous-titres de la langue de notre choix.]

Une fois lancés, l'aventure se révèle être plaisante à suivre. Les lieux sont charmeurs, la patte du dessinateur est douce et très agréable, quant aux personnages, ils sont cocasses et hauts en couleurs. On va très vite se rendre compte que la comédie est le pilier de ce voyage qui fleure bon le [i]british humour[/i] décomplexé. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=660888560 Les quêtes restent elles-aussi dans le même esprit, drôles et parfois assez originales (retrouver le sens d'expressions propres à la piraterie, déduire l'emplacement des bateaux dans le port en lisant le registre du Commodore, trouver le moyen de saboter la course qui oppose de loufoques riches désargentés, trouver le signe astrologique du cuistot chinois pour réussir à le berner...etc). L'imagination n'est clairement pas en reste à ce niveau-là.

Toutefois, au bout d'un moment on va se sentir un peu perdus par l'avalanche de quêtes, et surtout de quêtes "enchâssées". Par exemple (petit spoiler alert), il nous faudra construire un détecteur d'oiseaux afin de retrouver la trace des bestioles disparues. Il nous faut donc une tige en or et tiens, il y a justement une épée en or chez le marchand de babioles mais (oui ce n'est jamais si simple) ce dernier ne la cèdera qu'en cas d'attaque navale. Il faut lui faire croire à une attaque et on aura donc besoin d'un leurre. Pour obtenir l'objet en question il faudra rapporter une bière bien particulière à un PNJ tiers et pour obtenir cette bière il faudra aider le barman qui ne s'en sort plus avec ses fûts. Pfiou ! Et ce n'est là que pour un objet parmi d'autres. On va donc se retrouver dans des situations où on se demandera : "pourquoi j'ai besoin de ce truc en fait ?" ou "attends je dois aider ce type pour qu'il me donne ce bidule pour qu'un autre type me donne un autre bidule, c'est ça ?". http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=663565888 Heureusement à nos côtés se trouve Sebastien, un oiseau qui pourra nous rafraichir la mémoire quant à nos quêtes, nous offrir des informations sur des personnages et nous aider en interagissant avec l'environnement. De même, les allers-retours sont facilités par la présence d'une carte des lieux, ce qui est appréciable étant donné le nombre de va-et-vient que l'on à l'habitude de faire dans les jeux de ce type.

Si je dois évoquer de petits défauts supplémentaires, j'ajouterais qu'un certain puzzle qui demandait de l'adresse était plutôt malvenu. [url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=662902271]Vous savez, une sorte de "Docteur Maboul" comme on a tous connu en jeu de plateau[/url], sauf que là c'est un simple dessin et qu'aucun élément ne nous donne d'indication sur la profondeur de champ. On va donc toucher des bords invisibles sans arrêt. La technique ? Faire doucement et trouver le bon chemin à force d'essais, moyen comme puzzle.
Par ailleurs, la musique du jeu est sympathique et entrainante mais très oubliable aussi pour le coup. Les doublages, bien qu'inégaux selon les personnages (j'aurai aimé que l'actrice qui interprète Nelly ait une voix moins "froide" mais ce n'est que mon ressenti) restent d'une qualité convaincante.

En tout et pour tout, Nelly Cootalot est un point & click de bonne qualité qui, bien qu'il soit perfectible, n'a pas à rougir à côté des plus grands jeux du genre. Humour, loufoquerie, belle galerie de lieux et de personnages, quêtes intéressantes, il ne manque qu'un peu de créativité au niveau de la bande-son et un meilleur agencement des quêtes pour éviter ce sentiment de "fouillis" que l'on ressent lorsque l'on débute une nouvelle zone. La recette du bon point & click est presque maitrisée, les backers ont bien eu raison de soutenir le jeu sur Kickstarter !

[i] Une clé à été fournie à des fin d'évaluations par le site [url=www.gamesidestory.com]Game Side Story[/url] sur lequel vous retrouverez cette évaluation prochainement.[/i]

22326165.review:
A gem of a game.  I've been slowly working my wy through Nelly Cootalot, and thoroughly enjoying the experience.  The classic Lucas Arts games of the 90s set a tremendously high bar for point and click adventures, and I'm always a little trepidatious when starting to play a new one.  Thankfully, Nelly nails all the key elements that a good point a click adventure needs.

The hand drawn artwork is lovely throughout.  It looks like a lot of time and love has been spent on all the backgrounds and characters.  The voice acting is generally of a high standard, and most importantly Nelly herself has great humour and charm with which she delivers her lines.  

The puzzles are sometimes easy, sometimes tricky, and I haven't yet been stuck frustratingly on anything for too long.  Most importantly the game has oodles of humour, and the next laugh, chuckle or guffaw is never far away.

If you like your games funny, charming, and engrossing then this is one to pick up.

22121477.review:
I’ve [url=http://lparchive.org/Nelly-Cootalot/]LP’d the previous installment[/url], Kickstarted the sequel, and was rather looking forward to this. Let’s break down my impressions, from least important to the most:

Graphics: I kinda miss the original hand-drawn look. It had a unique charm to it that the smoother and less unique 3d models lack. 

Voicework: Quite good all around. Except from some British TV guy – apparently everyone were so excited to have him on that they forgot to check whether his voice fits the character.

Controls: Remarkably bad, by adventure game standards. Everything feels a bit sluggish and slow to react to commands. Whenever you try to click two items in quick succession (quick = within a second or two) the game is sure to get confused and randomly misapply your clicks. 

Puzzle quality: Generally decent – moderately challenging at times, but logical and sensible. You never have to resort to random item combinations, your inventory is emptied of formerly useful items in regular intervals, and the big puzzle sets require just the right amount of thought. I got stuck on two separate occasions – one is a bit of accidental misinformation the developer promised to remove, while the other was a random piece of the puzzle stuck in a cluttered screen where it had no reason to be.
HOWEVER. There are mini-games scattered at regular intervals, and they are terrible at conveying their control schemes and victory conditions. 

Writing quality: Maintains the quirky charm of the original, has a few laugh out loud moments every so often (helped by the voice work and decent comic timing). However, every so often you’ll get a random meme shoved in, not at all meshing with the overall writing style. The game has an “arrow to the knee” joke. In 2016(!)
Also, I think the ending and the airship section were severely cut during the production stage, and it SHOWS. Just a bit of a mess from the writing perspective.

Overall: 7/10. Cute and charming, if not a particularly innovative. It’s probably a bit too late to actually fix the ending into something coherent, but improving the controls, mini-game instructions and dumping the memes would bump the rating up to 8/10.

22105791.review:
First things first, I should mention that one of my friends was involved in the production of this game -- and voices a pompous sea bird -- and I've spent an afternoon playing [i]Bomberman[/i] with both the creator of the game and Nelly Cootalot herself, or at least her inspiration and voice actor.

[i]Nelly Cootalot: The Fowl Fleet[/i] is a comedic point and click adventure game about pirates. If you are now thinking "Gosh, that's a bit like deciding to be a sprinter and challenging Usain Bolt to a race your first time out" then that's a bit weird that we both thought of that, but you'd be correct. The shadow of [i]Monkey Island[/i] looms large over this game -- now I'm imagining a Lovecraft pastiche; [i]The Shadow Over Monkey Island[/i] -- but not only does the script acknowledge the influence, Nelly Cootalot is strong enough to stand up to and apart from its illustrious predecessor.

The writing for the most part is strong, and the characters' personalties come across well, helped in no small part by good voice acting throughout. Nelly herself is a charming protagonist; everyone seems to like her, and her cheerful approach to adventure is infectious. The main villains are a bit sketchy, and not in the appropriate sense of the word; I think they return from the original game in the series, but as I've not played that, their motivations and personalities seem a bit vague in this instalment. A new villain introduced in the middle section of the game comes across far better, although again his motivations and connection to the main plot are somewhat unclear. Still, it's Nelly and her friends who are most important and they are well-written and acted; aside from Nelly herself, I was most impressed by her sidekick Sebastian, voiced by Tom "[i]Warhammer 40,000: Fire Warrior[/i]" Baker. To be honest, I was expecting someone of Sir Tom's prestige to sleepwalk through his role but he brings a lot of personality to Sebastian, even though he has one of those voices that means you can never quite forget that there's an actor behind the character.

The game is funny, and there's a varied approach to the jokes, with plenty of references to films and games, a bit of witty wordplay, a dash of satire here and there, and at least one bit of smutty innuendo, although that last one doesn't land as well as it could have due to some clumsy back-pedalling. Some comments and reviews have claimed that the game is for children -- perhaps because of the art style -- but the latter joke suggests not, and some of the references are going to go right over the heads of most kids, unless they are showing Jack Nicholson films in primary schools these days.

The game looks good too. The trailers did look a bit ropey, with a flat animation style reminiscent of Flash or a cheap CBeebies programme, but the game itself looks much better. The character models look to be cel-shaded and that gives them a bit more weight, and they are for the most part well-animated; it is a bit of a shame that they don't tend to do anything when Nelly isn't interacting with them, but one has to remember that this isn't a multi-million pound game with a hundred-strong creative team behind it. That said, it's a pleasant surprise when you spot a character making a small movement or gesture that must have added time to the production schedule and is irrelevant to wider game, but helps to bring the character to life. It shows a dedication and craftsmanship that you don't often see in the aforementioned larger productions.

I did encounter a couple of graphical glitches; during one part of the Guttering Howls section Nelly walks in front of and through something she should be behind, and in the penultimate chapter the inventory panel goes a bit wonky, but is still usable. I also had a bit of trouble with the game's interface being slow to register what was under the pointer, although the mechanics worked as expected, so it wasn't a major issue. I played the game on Linux Mint 17.3 and I don't know if these glitches are in every port.

Heh, "port". Like sailors. Heh.

[i]Nelly Cootalot[/i]'s puzzles are varied and often require different approaches and techniques to solve; even when they are of the give-item-A-to-person-B sort, they are at least presented in novel ways so the game never gets dull. In terms of difficulty, the puzzles are if not simple, then logical, so you are never hunting for rogue pixels or throwing every item at every character, hoping for the best.

That said if there is a flaw in [i]Nelly Cootalot[/i] -- and to be fair, it is the only thing I would consider a proper flaw -- it's the wider game and story logic surrounding the puzzles. On a few occasions I worked out the solution to a problem, and had all the correct items in my inventory ready to go, but I couldn't apply said solution because I hadn't gone to talk to someone -- often in another location -- who was supposed to give me the idea I'd already had. This led to frustration and -- in one case near the end of the game -- a suspicion that there was a game-breaking bug. On the plus side, Sebastian is able to give hints about what to do next, and in at least one case this helped resolve the impasse, although in the latter instance I did end up roaming around clicking on everything and everyone until I spoke to the right person.

Creator Alasdair Beckett-King is a jolly nice fellow -- and is not bad at [i]Bomberman[/i] -- but it turns out he's quite good at making computer games too. I had great fun playing [i]Nelly Cootalot: The Fowl Fleet[/i] and although it is short -- it can be completed in about five hours or so, although getting the Steam achievements will take longer -- I think it is worth the £12 I paid for it. There are rough edges, and places where I feel Alasdair and his team could have done a tiny bit more, but what's here is good, and I hope the game is enough of a success that we see more from him.

If you like point and click adventure games, give this a try because you'll probably ike it. If you don't, give it a try anyway, as it's charming and funny and may change your mind.

Cons:

In Conclusion, Nelly Cootalot: The Fowl Fleet is a fantastic click and play game that measures up to the best of them, I highly recommend this game, well worth the price and will give hours of entertainment. 5 out of 5, and winner of the Dragon Games Award.

22074676.review:
Nelly Cootalot: The Fowl Fleet is great fun. The animation and art are wonderful and the voice acting was some of truly best I've ever heard. Having backed its Kickstarter ages ago, I was very well pleased with the money spent and I would have no qualms about backing them again.

It's only drawback for me is that it's rather short. I finished it in about 5.5 hours, and that's looking at every single thing. 

I would certainly recommend it, though. It's puzzles are well plotted and are much more logical than a lot of adventure games of old, but on the easy side for anyone who's played many adventure games. I've been playing them for over 20 years and had very little trouble with any of them. 

There were a couple of bugs that I noticed. The cursor doesn't always change once you take it off of an item and hover over a different one (for example, you look at Crow's Nest and then Roof, but the cursor will still say Crow's Nest, even though it gives you information on Roof if you click on it). The other bug is when Nelly is supposed to be walking up a hill behind a building. It looks as though she's walking up the front of the building instead.

The only other thing I would say is that if you want to have a go at getting all of the achievements, they aren't all working yet. The final one (the Timewaster, the one for having achieved all the others) doesn't show up, despite having all the other 19. I had enough pleasure in playing the game, though, that I will go back and play it again once that's fixed.

22053129.review:
Nelly Cootalot: The Fowl Fleet is a fairly straightforward game that does not make you stop and think too long about each puzzle or force you to combine items aimlessly to figure out what to do next. Your goals are simple, and the way to accomplish them is often hinted at with just an ounce of subtlety by dialogue or object descriptions. The first minigame was the only one I didn't really grasp, and I still made it on my first try with a lucky guess. The others could have used some explanation at least for using their interfaces like Daedalic did for the Deponia series, but trial and error doesn't punish you for failure, so you can just figure it out on your own.

The main selling point of the game would be its humor, which had me not only smile at the numerous puns but genuinely laugh out loud at some of the main character's quips. Nelly herself is another high point of the game with her endearing mix of lawlessness and cluelessness. Her remarks make you want to look at every object twice to make sure you hear all the clever little things she has to say about them.

Overall the game is a bit on the short side (a little over 5 hours for me), but a fun and relaxing interactive adventure throughout. Likely an excellent choice to introduce your kids to the genre!

This is a charming and surprising game, sufficiently so it's prompted me to create my first Steam review. I purchased it as a Kickstarter backer and I was hoping for an amusing little adventure for the low price I paid, but was prepared for disappointment (I've backed Godus, Massive Chalice, Planetary Annihilation after all...). 

I didn't expect to be so relaxed and smiling within a couple of minutes of starting, or the quality of voice acting to be so high (Doctor Who ! The main character's great, also).

Overall Nelly Cootalot is to adventure games and Kickstarter, what FTL is to roguelikes and Kickstarter.

22001365.review:
Nelly Cootalot: The Fowl Fleet is the follow-up to the popular 2007 freeware adventure, [url=http://www.adventuregamestudio.co.uk/site/games/game/860/]Spoonbeaks Ahoy![/url], which won five AGS Awards and was nominated for seven more. In this game, we're introduced to our heroine Nelly Cootalot in a tutorial set aboard the mailship Undeliverable. Here you'll learn how to interact with other characters, to examine, pick up and use items, and how to combine them in your inventory. This is also where you learn of the villanous Baron Widebeard's evil plans, which involves a fleet of hypnotised birds.

As a bird-lover and defender of adorable creatures, Nelly wants none of that, and sets off in pursuit of Widebeard to his last known location. In order to progress from there, you must figure out the Baron's next destination by correctly applying information from a log book to a wall chart of ship departures—a puzzle that is one of my favorites in the game. You also have to gain permission to leave the docks by helping the miserable Admiral Woebegone by solving a classic "three trials" style branching puzzle.

Your next leg of the journey takes you to the main area of the game, which is a large area of three connected islands. Among other things, it has two main streets, several stores, food and drink establishments and a few public service buildings. In short, most of what you'd expect of an actual town, and it reminds me of memorable areas of the classics, such as Rubacava and the towns of the Tri-Island Area. Luckily, you can double-click on exits to teleport, and there's also a map you can use for fast-travel.

This is also the most diverse area in the puzzle department, and it is where you'll spend most of your time with the game. A puzzle revolving around a pirate-ified version of the classic board game Operation offered the biggest challenge to me, but since there are several other puzzles to tackle, I never felt completely stuck. If you do though, you can always get your bird companion Sebastian to give you a recap of your current objectives, without running the risk of spoiling anything.

A location placed inside the subconsious of a shaman monkey is also worth mentioning, but unfortunately it was all over rather quickly. There's also one large Viking inspired area left after that, but I don't want to spoil more than I already have.

The game features high-quality voice acting from a large cast of talented British actors, including Tom Baker of [i]Doctor Who[/i] and [i]Little Britain[/i]. It is also of the funnier games I have played, which should come as no surprise if you played the previous game or witnessed the Kickstarter pitch video or any of the YouTube announcements leading up to the release.

As a Kickstarter backer, I have participated in the beta since January, and I've been impressed by the developers, who have been very responsive in fixing all of the tricky Linux issues that cropped during the beta, and made me feel like a first-class customer. They have also been exceptionally friendly througout what must have been a long and stressful crunch.

My first playthrough of the beta took me 5–6 hours, according to my notes, but I've seen estimates of much longer play times, and it's of course highly dependent on your previous experience with the genre. A few of the puzzles felt a bit underwhelming, including a certain barrel puzzle and the finale. Other than that though, the game feels solid throughout, and I think it's a good all-rounder that will appeal to most players. 

[b]NOTE:[/b] This review was originally posted on [url=https://www.gamingonlinux.com/articles/a-review-of-point-and-click-adventure-nelly-cootalot-the-fowl-fleet-now-on-steam-.6869/]GamingOnLinux[/url]

21988679.review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PGjZE8PWoQE

[h1]Overview[/h1]

There was a time when Nelly was somewhat of a great pirate. She saved the Spoonbeaks once upon a time but now she’s a lowly mail clerk on a mail ship. Her ol’ ghost pirate pal, Bloodbeard, shows up to let her know that her great enemy Widebeard is up to his old tricks again. This time he’s manipulating the Spoonbeaks and various other beards and using them to do his bidding. Now Nelly must find Widebeard and stop him before he releases his Fowl Fleet! 

[h1]Visuals[/h1]

Nelly Cootalot: The Fowl Fleet is the sequel to an Adventure Game Studio title called Nelly Cootalot: Spoonbeaks Ahoy! While that game featured a hand drawn 2D style of gameplay. The Fowl Fleet is beautifully rendered in vibrant 3D visuals. The animations for the various characters and actions are simple but sweet. Don’t expect too much wacky movement outside of a few cut scenes and you should be golden. 

The world of Nelly Cootalot likes to keep it simple, but there are still plenty of kicks to get out of the characters movements. One particularly humorous example is after Nelly helps a bird move to a new home, and he thanks her by giving her a hat full of his poop before sliding away into his new nest. It’s simple and sweet and adds a different sort of hilarity to the world. 

[h1]Story[/h1]

Nelly Cootalot is a comedic adventure title and it never stops reminding us. Nelly is gung-ho but completely dimwitted at the same time. She’s like a stupider version of Drax from Guardians of the Galaxy. She takes most anything people tell her literally, so she’ll end up asking ridiculous questions or won’t fully understand basic innuendo. 

Luckily, a wide variety of the people she meets are quick to crack a few jokes or two. One of my favorite characters in the game is named, “Gusty Nethers.” Yeah… that’s right… Gusty Nethers. He also has a few other ridiculous names he starts to call himself over the course the game. Gusty is just one of many characters that don’t take themselves too seriously. It makes for some wonderful back and forth banter between Nelly and the various characters.

[h1]Sound[/h1]

There are some downsides and most of it comes in the form of the voice acting. It’s not to say that the voice acting is bad, in fact a lot of it is great. It’s that the jokes fall flat because the timing or the emotion isn’t particularly perfect. Sometimes Nelly or another character will tell a joke and there is no oomph to it whatsoever. Other times there will be a witty back and forth and the timing of a joke is just not enough to evoke laughter. It’s the moments like these that are a bit of a drawback to The Fowl Fleet, because it’s filled with hit and miss jokes. 

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

When it comes to the mechanics of the title. The team sought to make a game that isn’t just ham-fisted with combining items and clicking things. There are quite a few thoughtful puzzles in the game that think outside the box. Lots of the brainteasers rely on some well thought out and even nostalgic design choices. The enigma of it all functions by figuring out elements of a puzzle and piecing it altogether to create one cohesive part. 

A sample of this is one of the first real puzzles, where Nelly has to figure out the route of a fleet of ships by studying a log. Using different days as a reference you have to piece together the name and location of a ship she has to board. There are a variation of moments like these that shirk the usual “Click on random things” design of most adventure titles. Nelly Cootalot gives me a Professor Layton vibe as it consistently gives us amusing and well-thought out puzzles to enjoy. 

Nelly Cootalot may not be a particularly hard game, but how many Adventure games truly are? Most of them are difficult because you didn’t click the right objects, or you missed some dialogue that you can’t see again. Nelly Cootalot never leaves you lingering for too long on one of the many riddles. If you interact with the characters and observe the items, you’ll zip through the game without being tied down by boring pixel clicking.

I appreciate this, because I do enjoy the experience and the story of adventure games more than being stranded on Puzzle Island. I like to be challenged but not to the point where I’m stuck in one specific area for three hours because of something I didn’t notice. Nelly Cootalot: The Fowl Fleet is middle of the road in difficulty and I’m perfectly fine with that. 

[h1]Issues[/h1]

I have some early build concerns that hopefully will be addressed in the retail version. The first area of the game is ripe with UI and scrolling problems. The item slot would occasionally stay on-screen which impeded my ability to interact with anything else. Also, there were times when the screen would stop scrolling and I couldn’t walk to an area I needed to visit.  This game doesn’t realize when you’re using dual-monitors and uses the secondary screen instead. I had to switch to single-screen settings if I wanted to record video of the game. 

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

Nelly Cootalot: The Fowl Fleet started off as something I would have dismissed because it was trying too hard to be funny. It’s not until I ran into the first real puzzle before I said, “Hey, this is actually different for an adventure game.” Suddenly, I was hankering for the next new puzzle and engaged in solving any riddle that came my way.  

I began to appreciate the simplistic animations and suddenly fell in love with the world of Nelly Cootalot. If you’re looking for an entertaining and different Adventure title, Nelly Cootalot might be the game with just enough charm to draw you in. Nelly is no Guybrush Threepwood, but she is certainly in a position to take over where he left off.

21988253.review:
This game is like a cute younger sibling to Monkey Island.

I backed Nelly Cootalot: The Fowl Fleet on Kickstarter, because I was a fan of the previous Nelly Cootalot game. I loved the background art, but was skeptical on how well the new character designs were going to work. Playing the game, the character designs did really grow on me, so I'd say don't write it off if you have the same initial issue. The puzzles are typical for a point-and-click adventure, with nothing too challenging. Really, this game is about its great sense of humor. 21987855.review:
Nelly Cootalot: The Fowl Fleet surprised me. The game's story/setting is charming/quirky and I enjoyed it a lot more than I was expecting. There are quite a few funny moments in the game as well.  The story might not appeal to everyone but I enjoyed it quite a bit. 

The puzzles are pretty clever and well designed. Unlike some point and click adventure games the puzzles aren't obtuse where you have to guess your ways to the correct answer. The game is just really well made. 

I really only had two complaints with Nelly Cootalot: The Fowl Fleet. First the game is kind of on the shorter side. The game lasts around five to six hours. Since I was really enjoying the game I wish it was a little longer. The other problem is that for the most part I found the game to be kind of easy. You probably aren't going to be really challenged by the game. 

Although not totally necessary, I would recommend playing the original game first. You won't be lost if you don't play the first game but the game does sometimes address things that happen in the first game so you might be slightly confused a couple times in the game. The original game can be found online for free.

If you like point and click adventure games I think you will enjoy Nelly Cootalot: The Fowl Fleet.

Note: I received a review copy from the developer but received no other compensation for this review.

21987227.review:
Análisis publicado en http://arsgaming.com/nelly-cootalot-the-fowl-fleet-analisis

Application Systems nos trae Nelly Cootalot, un juego que rescata todo el humor de Monkey Island. Nos pondremos bajo la piel de una despreocupada y divertida protagonista en una aventura gráfica que llamará la atención y arrancará más de una carcajada a los nostálgicos y fans del género.

Este título es la segunda aventura de Nelly Cootalot, cuya primera parte fue publicada en 2007 y se encuentra disponible para descargar de manera gratuita. Si bien las aventuras gráficas de point & click no viven su mejor momento en cuanto a proyección, este título rescata el tono humorístico con referencias tronchantes y una magnífica adaptación de los chistes al castellano, aspecto que hace que un juego de este estilo sea capaz de llegar correctamente a la comunidad hispanohablante.

El argumento es sencillo, Nelly Cootalot, que sueña con ser pirata, se ve tentada para embarcarse en una gran aventura para detener al Baron Barbancha. Y como no puede ser de otra manera en este tipo de historias es la aparición de un legendario pirata al que Nelly admira, William Barbasangrienta, el detonante que inicia la gesta. Este se aparece en forma de espíritu y le pide que desbarate los malévolos planes del Barón Barbancha que intenta robar su tesoro oculto. Tendremos por tanto que seguir los pasos de Barbancha mientras nos vamos labrando una reputación, hacemos amigos y nos enfrentamos a villanos locales. Toda la historia se desarrolla en clave de humor, un aspecto que va desde los nombres a los personajes a multitud de referencias. Encontraremos alusiones a temas y personajes actuales y clásicos. Asimismo vamos a encontrar incluso referencias a clásicos literarios con guiños sutiles y no tan sutiles que sin duda ayudan a hacer que el jugador se sienta partícipe de la historia. Entre algunas de las referencias que encontramos se encuentran los Rolling Stones, nombres de personajes de obras de Shakespeare, referencias a actores como Cristopher Lee e incluso a la quiebra de Lehman Brothers.

En cuanto a las mecánicas de juego no hay grandes novedades si lo comparamos con otras aventuras gráficas de point & click. Tendremos que recorrer el mapeado hablando con los personajes, recolectando objetos y combinándolos. Esto nos permitirá avanzar en la trama y llegar a nuevas áreas. Asimismo tendremos que ir resolviendo problemas de los diferentes personajes que nos vayamos encontrando y entre algunas de las actividades que tengamos que realizar se encuentra la de resolver algunos puzles con informaciones que se nos dan o memorizar de cara a responder a preguntas de otros personajes. Algunas de estas misiones que tendremos que completar para avanzar son ordenar un tablero con diferentes barcos a través de unas notas, ordenar barriles o buscar palabras de la jerga pirata. También hay algún minijuego que tendremos que superar para conseguir ciertos objetivos lo que le da una sensación de variedad al título.

La resolución de los acertijos y de ciertos puzles se puede tornar en algunos momentos más dura a causa de que hayamos pasado por alto algún elemento del escenario, por lo que tendremos que revisarlos muy bien y visitar las zonas varias veces.

Si en una de estas ocasiones en las que nos quedemos atascados optásemos, ya sea por cuestiones de tiempo o de frustración, por dejar el juego apartado durante un tiempo, tenemos a un compañero que nos ayudará: Sebastián. Este se nos unirá en los primeros compases de la partida y podremos valernos de él para ciertas tareas. Además nos dará consejos sobre las tareas que tenemos pendientes, lo que nos permite recuperar el hilo de la trama.

El apartado sonoro y gráfico va mucho más allá que la primera entrega, algo que le ha permitido su éxito en Kickstarter. Las ilustraciones artísticas dotan de una gran calidad a los paisajes aunque es cierto que las animaciones son algo rústicas, algo que por otro lado es común en juegos del mismo estilo. En cuanto a la música es entretenida y amena aunque el hilo musical se nos puede hacer algo pesado si jugamos mucho tiempo seguido, ya que no es excesivamente largo.

En definitiva, Nelly Cootalot: The Fowl Fleet es un título hecho para los jugadores clásicos que disfrutan con una aventura gráfica pura y que quieren pasar un rato riendo con las ocurrencias de Nelly.

Eins gleich vornab: Nelly Cootalot ist ein Fest für alle Freunde des "speziellen" Humors, des point & clicks und der märchenhaften Adventures. Zwar ist dieses Spiel hier ein "Piraten"spiel, ist jedoch sehr verspielt gehalten, wirkt teilweise schon fast kindlich. Die Dialoge sind synchronisiert, komplett deutsche Sprachausgabe ist vorhanden und wir reden und "kombinieren" uns vor allem durchs Spiel in alter point & click Manier: Gegenstände anklicken, einen Spruch dazu zum Besten geben oder rein damit ins Inventar und verbinden mit dem Nächsten. Die Storyline und die Komik machen dies jedoch zu einem sehr unterhaltsamen Zeitvertreib und lassen es eher als (Trick)filmerlebnis durchgehen. Ich bin absolut begeistert von dem Spiel - jeder, ders ruhig, kurzweilig und etwas "verrückt" mag, sei hierzu eingeladen!
